001package io.github.ai4ci.config.execution;
002
003import static io.github.ai4ci.functions.SimpleDistribution.unimodalBeta;
004
005import java.io.Serializable;
006import java.lang.reflect.Method;
007
008import org.immutables.value.Value;
009
010import com.fasterxml.jackson.annotation.JsonIgnore;
011import com.fasterxml.jackson.databind.annotation.JsonDeserialize;
012import com.fasterxml.jackson.databind.annotation.JsonSerialize;
013
014import io.github.ai4ci.abm.Abstraction;
015import io.github.ai4ci.abm.ModelUpdate.PersonUpdaterFn;
016import io.github.ai4ci.abm.OutbreakState;
017import io.github.ai4ci.abm.PersonBaseline;
018import io.github.ai4ci.abm.PersonDemographic;
019import io.github.ai4ci.abm.TestResult;
020import io.github.ai4ci.abm.behaviour.BehaviourModel;
021import io.github.ai4ci.abm.behaviour.ReactiveTestAndIsolate;
022import io.github.ai4ci.abm.policy.PolicyModel;
023import io.github.ai4ci.abm.policy.ReactiveLockdown;
024import io.github.ai4ci.abm.policy.Trigger;
025import io.github.ai4ci.abm.riskmodel.RiskModel;
026import io.github.ai4ci.config.TestParameters;
027import io.github.ai4ci.config.inhost.InHostConfiguration;
028import io.github.ai4ci.config.inhost.PhenomenologicalModel;
029import io.github.ai4ci.example.Kernels;
030import io.github.ai4ci.flow.mechanics.StateUtils;
031import io.github.ai4ci.functions.DelayDistribution;
032import io.github.ai4ci.functions.DiscreteFunction;
033import io.github.ai4ci.functions.Distribution;
034import io.github.ai4ci.functions.EmpiricalKernel;
035import io.github.ai4ci.functions.GaussianKernel;
036import io.github.ai4ci.functions.KernelFunction;
037import io.github.ai4ci.util.ShallowList;
038
039/**
040 * Central configuration for executing epidemiological Agent-Based Model
041 * simulations.
042 *
043 * <p>
044 * Controls all aspects of ABM execution including:
045 * <ul>
046 * <li>Disease transmission parameters (R0, progression rates)</li>
047 * <li>Contact patterns and mobility</li>
048 * <li>Intervention policies (testing, lockdowns)</li>
049 * <li>Behavioral responses by individuals</li>
050 * <li>Within-host disease progression</li>
051 * </ul>
052 *
053 * <p>
054 * The configuration influences both:
055 * <ul>
056 * <li>Population-level dynamics (through policies and global parameters)</li>
057 * <li>Individual behaviors (through contact patterns, compliance, testing)</li>
058 * </ul>
059 *
060 * <p>
061 * Example usage:
062 *
063 * <pre>{@code
064 * ExecutionConfiguration config = ExecutionConfiguration.DEFAULT
065 *              .withReplicate(1).withName("scenario1");
066 * }</pre>
067 *
068 * @author Rob Challen
069 * @see BehaviourModel
070 * @see PolicyModel
071 * @see InHostConfiguration
072 */
073@Value.Immutable
074@JsonSerialize(as = ImmutableExecutionConfiguration.class)
075@JsonDeserialize(as = ImmutableExecutionConfiguration.class)
076public interface ExecutionConfiguration
077                extends Abstraction.Named, Abstraction.Replica, Serializable,
078                DemographicAdjustment.Execution<Distribution, Double> {
079
080        /**
081         * Default immutable configuration instance with baseline epidemiological
082         * parameters.
083         *
084         * <p>
085         * This configuration provides reasonable defaults for:
086         * <ul>
087         * <li>Transmission (R0=1.75)</li>
088         * <li>Disease severity (5% hospitalisation, 1% fatality)</li>
089         * <li>Testing (1% screening probability)</li>
090         * <li>Contact patterns (50% baseline contact probability)</li>
091         * <li>Behaviour models (ReactiveTestAndIsolate)</li>
092         * <li>Policy models (ReactiveLockdown)</li>
093         * </ul>
094         *
095         * <p>
096         * Population-level impacts:
097         * <ul>
098         * <li>Defines baseline transmission potential</li>
099         * <li>Sets lockdown triggers (5% positivity to start, 1% to release)</li>
100         * <li>Configures default testing parameters</li>
101         * </ul>
102         *
103         * <p>
104         * Individual-level impacts:
105         * <ul>
106         * <li>Sets baseline contact probabilities</li>
107         * <li>Configures symptom reporting behavior</li>
108         * <li>Defines compliance rates (99% baseline)</li>
109         * </ul>
110         */
111        public static ImmutableExecutionConfiguration DEFAULT = ImmutableExecutionConfiguration
112                        .builder().setName("execution").setR0(1.75)
113                        .setAsymptomaticFraction(0.5).setCaseHospitalisationRate(0.05)
114                        .setCaseFatalityRate(0.01)
115
116                        .setContactProbability(unimodalBeta(0.5, 0.25))
117                        // .setContactProbability(uniform())
118                        .setAppUseProbability(unimodalBeta(0.97, 0.1))
119                        .setContactDetectedProbability(0.9)
120
121                        .setComplianceProbability(unimodalBeta(0.99, 0.1))
122
123//                      .setRiskTrigger( Distribution.point(0.05) )
124//                      .setRiskTriggerRatio(1.1)
125//                      .setHighRiskMobilityModifier(0.95)
126//                      .setHighRiskTransmissibilityModifier(0.95)
127
128                        .setInHostConfiguration(PhenomenologicalModel.DEFAULT)
129
130                        .setLockdownStartTrigger(0.05).setLockdownReleaseTrigger(0.01)
131                        .setLockdownTriggerValue(Trigger.Value.SCREENING_TEST_POSITIVITY)
132
133//                      .setLockdownMinDuration(14)
134//                      .setLockdownMobility(0.5)
135//                      .setLockdownTransmissibility(0.5)
136
137//                      .setScreeningPeriod( Distribution.gamma(7.0,1D) )
138//                      .setProbabilityScreened(0.01)
139                        .setInitialScreeningProbability(0.01)
140
141                        .setDefaultBehaviourModelName(
142                                        ReactiveTestAndIsolate.class.getSimpleName()
143                        ).setDefaultPolicyModelName(ReactiveLockdown.class.getSimpleName())
144
145                        .setSymptomSensitivity(unimodalBeta(0.5, 0.1))
146                        .setSymptomSpecificity(unimodalBeta(0.95, 0.1))
147
148                        .setInitialEstimateSymptomSensitivity(0.5)
149                        .setInitialEstimateSymptomSpecificity(0.95)
150
151                        .setInitialEstimateIncubationPeriod(4.0)
152                        .setInitialEstimateInfectionDuration(10.0)
153
154                        .setRiskModelSymptomKernel(
155                                        Kernels.DEFAULT_SYMPTOM_ONSET_KERNEL.kernel()
156                        ).setRiskModelContactsKernel(Kernels.DEFAULT_CONTACT_KERNEL.kernel())
157                        .setRiskModelTestKernel(Kernels.DEFAULT_TEST_SAMPLE_KERNEL.kernel())
158
159                        .setMaximumSocialContactReduction(unimodalBeta(0.25, 0.1))
160                        .setAvailableTests(TestResult.defaultTypes())
161
162                        .setImportationProbability(0D)
163                        .setDemographicAdjustment(DemographicAdjustment.EMPTY)
164
165                        .setComplianceDeteriorationRate(0.02)
166                        .setComplianceImprovementRate(0.01)
167                        .setOrganicRateOfMobilityChange(1.0 / 4)
168
169                        .setSmartAppRiskTrigger(0.05)
170
171                        .build();
172
173        /**
174         * How likely was it that a person uses a contact tracing app?
175         *
176         * This distribution is sampled from for each person in the network to set
177         * their baseline probability of using a contact tracing app
178         * {@link PersonBaseline#getAppUseProbability()}. This parameter is important
179         * for modelling the effectiveness of digital contact tracing interventions,
180         * as higher app usage can lead to more effective identification and
181         * isolation of contacts, thereby reducing transmission. Adjusting this
182         * parameter allows for exploration of different scenarios regarding public
183         * adoption of contact tracing technologies.
184         * <p>
185         * Individual-level impact (PersonBaseline)
186         *
187         * @return a probability distribution of the population app usage
188         *         probability.
189         */
190        @Override
191        Distribution getAppUseProbability();
192
193        /**
194         * The fraction of infections that remain asymptomatic.
195         *
196         * This is used by the {@link io.github.ai4ci.abm.Calibration calibration} to
197         * set a threshold value for the normalised severity of the in-host model
198         * below which the patient is deemed to be asymptomatic.
199         *
200         * @return Value between 0 and 1
201         * @see #getInfectionCaseRate()
202         */
203        @Override
204        Double getAsymptomaticFraction();
205
206        /**
207         * Gets the set of available test types in the simulation. Each test type is
208         * defined by its parameters such as sensitivity, specificity, and turnaround
209         * time.
210         * <p>
211         * Standard defaults are provided for
212         * {@link io.github.ai4ci.abm.TestResult#defaultTypes() common test types}
213         * (e.g., PCR, Lateral Flow) but this can be customized to explore different
214         * testing strategies and their impact on outbreak dynamics.
215         *
216         * @return List of TestParameters defining the characteristics of each test
217         *         type available for use in the simulation.
218         */
219        ShallowList<TestParameters> getAvailableTests();
220
221        /**
222         * The case fatality rate for symptomatic cases. This is used by the
223         * {@link io.github.ai4ci.abm.Calibration calibration} to set a threshold
224         * value for the normalised severity of the in-host model above which the
225         * patient is deemed to have died.
226         *
227         * @return Value between 0 and 1
228         * @see #getInfectionFatalityRate()
229         */
230        @Override
231        Double getCaseFatalityRate();
232
233        /**
234         * The case hospitalisation rate for symptomatic cases. This is used by the
235         * {@link io.github.ai4ci.abm.Calibration calibration} to set a threshold
236         * value for the normalised severity of the in-host model above which the
237         * patient is deemed to be hospitalised.
238         *
239         * @return Value between 0 and 1
240         * @see #getInfectionHospitalisationRate()
241         */
242        @Override
243        Double getCaseHospitalisationRate();
244
245        /**
246         * The absolute rate of decrease in compliance in situations where the person
247         * is asked to self isolate. This is used direction by the behaviour models
248         * (via {@link StateUtils}) to determine how quickly an individual's
249         * compliance with isolation and other guidance deteriorates over time when
250         * they are asked to self isolate or are otherwise forced to do something.
251         * This parameter captures the phenomenon of "compliance fatigue". Although
252         * this is set across the whole population it is applied at the individual
253         * level and modifies an individual compliance probability that is set.
254         * <p>
255         * Population-level impact (BehaviourModel)
256         *
257         * @return Absolute rate of compliance deterioration (e.g., 0.02 per day)
258         * @see StateUtils#complianceFatigue(io.github.ai4ci.abm.ImmutablePersonState.Builder,
259         *      io.github.ai4ci.abm.PersonState)
260         */
261        Double getComplianceDeteriorationRate();
262        // N.B. Maybe this should be a distribution. or maybe more like organic rate
263        // of mobility change.
264
265        /**
266         * The absolute rate of decrease in compliance in situations where it is
267         * deemed to improve. This is used directly by the behaviour models (via
268         * {@link StateUtils}) to determine how quickly an individual's compliance
269         * with isolation and other guidance improves when they are not subject to
270         * restrictions and are otherwise free to do something. This parameter
271         * captures the phenomenon of "compliance recovery".
272         * <p>
273         * Population-level impact (BehaviourModel)
274         *
275         * @return Absolute rate of compliance improvement (e.g., 0.01 per day)
276         * @see StateUtils#complianceRestoreSlowly(io.github.ai4ci.abm.ImmutablePersonState.Builder,
277         *      io.github.ai4ci.abm.PersonState)
278         */
279        Double getComplianceImprovementRate();
280
281        /**
282         * How likely was it that a person complies with guidance?
283         *
284         * This distribution is sampled from for each person in the network to set
285         * their baseline probability of compliance with isolation
286         * {@link PersonBaseline#getComplianceBaseline()} and other guidance when
287         * they are asked to self isolate or testing is advised when they are deemed
288         * to be at high risk. This is a key parameter for the effectiveness of
289         * interventions and can be adjusted to reflect different levels of public
290         * adherence to health guidelines.
291         * <p>
292         * Individual-level impact (PersonBaseline)
293         *
294         * @return a probability distribution of the population compliance
295         *         probability.
296         */
297        @Override
298        Distribution getComplianceProbability();
299
300        /**
301         * How likely was it that a contact was detected?
302         *
303         * This describes the baseline probability that a contact with another person
304         * is detected and recorded
305         * {@link OutbreakState#getContactDetectedProbability()} given both
306         * participants are using an app and make contact. It describes the technical
307         * quality of a contact tracing app.
308         * <p>
309         * Population-level impact (OutbreakState):
310         *
311         * @return a probability.
312         */
313        Double getContactDetectedProbability();
314
315        /**
316         * The proportion of a persons social network that they see each day in a
317         * fully mobile population. The
318         * {@link io.github.ai4ci.abm.PersonBaseline#getMobilityBaseline() mobility
319         * baseline} is determined from this but as the contact is the product of 2
320         * peoples mobility the average probability of a contact will be the square
321         * of the central value. In the case of a Watts-Strogatz or similar social
322         * network setting this to be a uniform distribution is recommended to get an
323         * approximate scale free contact distribution.
324         * {@link io.github.ai4ci.abm.PersonBaseline#getMobilityBaseline()}
325         * <p>
326         * Individual-level impact (PersonBaseline):
327         * <ul>
328         * <li>Used to determine each person's baseline mobility</li>
329         * <li>Directly affects transmission probability between agents</li>
330         * </ul>
331         *
332         * @return Probability distribution (typically unimodal beta)
333         */
334        @Override
335        Distribution getContactProbability();
336
337        // @SuppressWarnings("unchecked")
338        /**
339         * Uses #getDefaultBehaviourModelName() to load the default behaviour model
340         * class and return the first value of the enum as the initial behaviour
341         * model for agents in the simulation. This allows for dynamic loading of
342         * behaviour models based on configuration.
343         *
344         * @return Default BehaviourModel instance corresponding to the name
345         *         specified in the configuration.
346         */
347        @JsonIgnore @Value.Lazy
348        default BehaviourModel getDefaultBehaviourModel() {
349                try {
350                        String name = this.getDefaultBehaviourModelName();
351                        if (!name.startsWith(BehaviourModel.class.getPackageName())) {
352                                name = BehaviourModel.class.getPackageName() + "." + name;
353                        }
354                        Class<?> clz = Class.forName(name);
355                        Method m = clz.getDeclaredMethod("values");
356                        BehaviourModel[] x = (BehaviourModel[]) m.invoke(null);
357                        return x[0];
358                } catch (Exception e) {
359                        throw new RuntimeException(
360                                        "Could not find behaviour model for: "
361                                                        + this.getDefaultBehaviourModelName(),
362                                        e
363                        );
364                }
365        }
366
367        /**
368         * Sets the initial behaviour model to be used by agents in the simulation.
369         * This defines the default behavioural response of agents to various
370         * triggers such as symptoms, test results, and policy interventions. The
371         * models are defined as enums implementing the {@link BehaviourModel}
372         * interface and can be extended to include custom behaviour models. The
373         * initial state the person starts with is the first value of the enum.
374         * <p>
375         * Individual-level impact (BehaviourModel)
376         *
377         * @return The simple name of the enum class implementing the default
378         *         BehaviourModel (e.g., "ReactiveTestAndIsolate") or the fully
379         *         qualified class name if it is not in the default package
380         *         ({@link io.github.ai4ci.abm.behaviour}).
381         */
382        String getDefaultBehaviourModelName();
383
384        /**
385         * Uses #getDefaultPolicyModelName() to load the default policy model class
386         * and return the first value of the enum as the initial policy model for the
387         * simulation. This allows for dynamic loading of policy models based on
388         * configuration.
389         *
390         * @return Default PolicyModel instance corresponding to the name specified
391         *         in the configuration.
392         */
393        @JsonIgnore @Value.Lazy
394        default PolicyModel getDefaultPolicyModel() {
395                try {
396                        String name = this.getDefaultPolicyModelName();
397                        if (!name.startsWith(PolicyModel.class.getPackageName())) {
398                                name = PolicyModel.class.getPackageName() + "." + name;
399                        }
400                        Class<?> clz = Class.forName(name);
401                        Method m = clz.getDeclaredMethod("values");
402                        PolicyModel[] x = (PolicyModel[]) m.invoke(null);
403                        return x[0];
404                } catch (Exception e) {
405                        throw new RuntimeException(
406                                        "Could not find policy model for: "
407                                                        + this.getDefaultPolicyModelName(),
408                                        e
409                        );
410                }
411        }
412
413        /**
414         * Sets the initial policy model to be used by the simulation. This defines
415         * the default policy response to the evolving outbreak. The models are
416         * defined as enums implementing the {@link PolicyModel} interface and can be
417         * extended to include custom models. The initial policy state is the first
418         * value of the enum.
419         * <p>
420         * Population-level impact (PolicyModel)
421         *
422         * @return The simple name of the enum class implementing the default
423         *         PolicyModel (e.g., "ReactiveLockdown") or the fully qualified
424         *         class name if it is not in the default package
425         *         ({@link io.github.ai4ci.abm.policy}).
426         */
427        String getDefaultPolicyModelName();
428
429        // Distribution getRiskTrigger();
430
431//      Double getRiskTriggerRatio();
432//      Double getHighRiskMobilityModifier();
433//      Double getHighRiskTransmissibilityModifier();
434
435//      Double getLockdownMobility();
436//      Double getLockdownTransmissibility();
437
438//      Distribution getScreeningPeriod();
439//      Double getProbabilityScreened();
440
441        /**
442         * Adjustment of different parameters as a function of age or other
443         * demographics. In general this specifies either single valued functions or
444         * probabilistic adjustments to parameters based on demographic
445         * characteristics. These adjustments are applied to the baseline parameters
446         * defined in this configuration to create demographic-specific parameters
447         * for individuals in the population. For example, if the case fatality rate
448         * is 1% in the baseline configuration and the demographic adjustment
449         * specifies an odds ratio of 2 for a certain age group, then the adjusted
450         * case fatality rate for that age group would be approximately 2%.
451         *
452         * <p>
453         * The exact method of adjustment depends on the type of parameter:
454         * probabilistic parameters will be adjusted as an odds ratio and other real
455         * values quantities will be simply scaled by the adjustment value.
456         * Adjustments are matched to their parameters by name and this is performed
457         * by
458         * {@link io.github.ai4ci.util.ReflectionUtils#modify(X, PartialDemographicAdjustment, PersonDemographic)}.
459         *
460         * <p>
461         * At the moment this is only defined for age but it could be extended to
462         * other demographics such as location, socioeconomic status, or
463         * comorbidities however multivariate distributions would be needed to
464         * capture interactions between demographics.
465         *
466         * <p>
467         * Individual-level impact (PersonBaseline)
468         *
469         * @return PartialDemographicAdjustment instance defining how parameters are
470         *         adjusted based on demographics.
471         *
472         * @see DemographicAdjustment.Execution
473         * @see DemographicAdjustment.Phenomenological
474         * @see DemographicAdjustment.Markov
475         */
476        PartialDemographicAdjustment getDemographicAdjustment();
477
478        /**
479         * This defines the probability of and individual with standard mobility
480         * being infected from outside the simulated population per time step. This
481         * will create a random exposure uniform across the population depending on
482         * individual mobility.
483         *
484         * This feature is experimental and may be revised or removed in future
485         * versions. It is likely that it will be replaced with temporal functions.
486         *
487         * @return Probability of external infection per time step for a fully mobile
488         *         individual (e.g., 0.001)
489         * @see PersonUpdaterFn#IMPORTATION_PROTOCOL
490         */
491        Double getImportationProbability();
492
493        /**
494         * The overall rate of symptomatic cases across the whole Outbreak.
495         *
496         * @return 1 - asymptomaticFraction
497         */
498        @JsonIgnore
499        default Double getInfectionCaseRate() {
500                return 1 - this.getAsymptomaticFraction();
501        }
502
503        /**
504         * The overall fatality rate across all infections across the whole Outbreak.
505         *
506         * @return infectionCaseRate * caseFatalityRate
507         */
508        @JsonIgnore
509        default Double getInfectionFatalityRate() {
510                return this.getInfectionCaseRate() * this.getCaseFatalityRate();
511        }
512
513        /**
514         * The overall hospitalisation rate across all infections across the whole
515         * Outbreak.
516         *
517         * @return infectionCaseRate * caseHospitalisationRate
518         */
519        @JsonIgnore
520        default Double getInfectionHospitalisationRate() {
521                return this.getInfectionCaseRate() * this.getCaseHospitalisationRate();
522        }
523
524        /**
525         * Gets the within-host disease progression configuration. The configuration
526         * defines the model used for simulating viral load dynamics, symptom onset,
527         * and disease severity in infected individuals.
528         *
529         * <p>
530         * Options include phenomenological models (e.g. viral load profiles based on
531         * empirical data) mechanistic Markov models of disease progression, and
532         * mechanistic stochastic compartment models.
533         *
534         * <p>
535         * Individual-level impact (InHostConfiguration):
536         * <ul>
537         * <li>Controls viral load dynamics in infected individuals</li>
538         * <li>Affects infectiousness profiles and symptom onset</li>
539         * </ul>
540         *
541         * @return InHostConfiguration instance
542         * @see io.github.ai4ci.config.inhost.PhenomenologicalModel
543         * @see io.github.ai4ci.config.inhost.MarkovStateModel
544         * @see io.github.ai4ci.config.inhost.StochasticModel
545         */
546        InHostConfiguration getInHostConfiguration();
547
548        /**
549         * The initial estimate of the duration of incubation period defines
550         * {@link io.github.ai4ci.abm.OutbreakState#getPresumedIncubationPeriod() the
551         * presumed incubation period} used in the initial outbreak state. The
552         * assumption of the incubation period affects decisions about the validity
553         * of recent tests.
554         * <p>
555         * Population-level impact (OutbreakState)
556         *
557         * @return Initial estimate of incubation period duration in days (e.g.,
558         *         10.0)
559         */
560        Double getInitialEstimateIncubationPeriod();
561
562        /**
563         * The initial estimate of the duration of infectiousness defines
564         * {@link io.github.ai4ci.abm.OutbreakState#getPresumedInfectiousPeriod() the
565         * presumed infectious period} used in the initial outbreak state. The
566         * assumption of infectious period affects the duration of interventions such
567         * as isolation.
568         * <p>
569         * Population-level impact (OutbreakState)
570         *
571         * @return Initial estimate of infectious period duration in days (e.g.,
572         *         10.0)
573         */
574        Double getInitialEstimateInfectionDuration();
575
576        /**
577         * The initial estimate of the duration of symptom sensitivity defines
578         * {@link io.github.ai4ci.abm.OutbreakState#getPresumedSymptomSensitivity()
579         * the presumed symptom sensitivity} used in the initial outbreak state. The
580         * assumption of the symptom sensitivity affects the calculation of perceived
581         * risk in the {@link RiskModel} resulting from symptoms.
582         * <p>
583         * Population-level impact (OutbreakState)
584         *
585         * @return Initial estimate of symptom sensitivity in terms of probability of
586         *         symptom onset when infected (e.g., 0.5)
587         */
588        Double getInitialEstimateSymptomSensitivity();
589        // N.b. It is not individualised but in theory could be adjusted for
590        // demographics (e.g. {@link DemographicAdjustment.Execution}.
591
592        /**
593         * The initial estimate of the duration of symptom specificity defines
594         * {@link io.github.ai4ci.abm.OutbreakState#getPresumedSymptomSpecificity()
595         * the presumed symptom specificity} used in the initial outbreak state. The
596         * assumption of the symptom specificity affects the calculation of perceived
597         * risk in the {@link RiskModel} resulting from symptoms.
598         * <p>
599         * Population-level impact (OutbreakState)
600         *
601         * @return Initial estimate of symptom specificity in terms of 1-probability
602         *         of false symptom onset when uninfected (e.g., 0.95)
603         */
604        Double getInitialEstimateSymptomSpecificity();
605
606        /**
607         * The baseline probability of random screening tests across the whole
608         * Outbreak.
609         *
610         * @return Value between 0 and 1
611         * @see #getAvailableTests()
612         */
613        Double getInitialScreeningProbability();
614
615        /**
616         * Gets prevalence trigger value for lifting lockdowns. Used directly by
617         * {@link io.github.ai4ci.abm.policy.ReactiveLockdown} to determine when to
618         * lift restrictions based on the monitored epidemiological indicator.
619         * <p>
620         * Population-level impact (PolicyModel):
621         * <ul>
622         * <li>Threshold trigger value to remove restrictions</li>
623         * <li>Provides hysteresis to prevent rapid cycling</li>
624         * </ul>
625         *
626         * @return Trigger value (typically 0.01)
627         * @see #getLockdownTriggerValue()
628         */
629        Double getLockdownReleaseTrigger();
630
631        /**
632         * Gets prevalence trigger value for initiating lockdowns. Used directly by
633         * {@link io.github.ai4ci.abm.policy.ReactiveLockdown} to determine when to
634         * activate restrictions based on the monitored epidemiological indicator.
635         * <p>
636         * Population-level impact (PolicyModel):
637         * <ul>
638         * <li>Threshold trigger value rate to activate restrictions</li>
639         * <li>Must be paired with PolicyModel implementation</li>
640         * </ul>
641         *
642         * @return Trigger value (typically 0.05)
643         * @see #getLockdownTriggerValue()
644         */
645        Double getLockdownStartTrigger();
646
647        /**
648         * The type of trigger used for lockdown policies. This defines the metric
649         * that is monitored to determine when to activate or lift lockdown measures.
650         * <p>
651         * Population-level impact:
652         * <ul>
653         * <li>Determines the epidemiological indicator used for lockdown
654         * decisions</li>
655         * <li>Common options include screening test positivity, symptomatic case
656         * rates, or hospitalisation rates</li>
657         * </ul>
658         *
659         * @return Trigger.Value enum indicating the type of trigger (e.g.,
660         *         SCREENING_TEST_POSITIVITY, SYMPTOMATIC_CASES,
661         *         HOSPITALISATION_RATE)
662         */
663        Trigger.Value getLockdownTriggerValue();
664
665        /**
666         * Each individual has a personal maximum that their social contact can be
667         * reduced by {@link PersonBaseline#getSelfIsolationDepth()}, which is
668         * sampled from this distribution. This in turn is used by the behaviour
669         * models to limit the maximum reduction in contact that an individual can
670         * achieve when they are asked to self isolate (via {@link StateUtils}).
671         *
672         * <p>
673         * Individual-level impact (PersonBaseline):
674         * <ul>
675         * <li>Determines the maximum possible reduction in social contacts for each
676         * agent</li>
677         * <li>Limits the effectiveness of self-isolation and other contact-reducing
678         * behaviors</li>
679         * </ul>
680         *
681         * @return Distribution representing the population-level variability in
682         *         maximum social contact reduction (e.g., unimodal beta distribution
683         *         with mean around 0.25 to reflect that most people can reduce
684         *         contacts by about 75% at most)
685         */
686        @Override
687        Distribution getMaximumSocialContactReduction();
688
689        /**
690         * Gets the decay rate of natural behaviour change in response to symptoms.
691         * This is used directly by the behaviour models (via {@link StateUtils}) to
692         * determine how quickly an individual's mobility reduces in response to
693         * symptoms and then recovers over time.
694         * <p>
695         * Individual-level impact:
696         * <ul>
697         * <li>Controls how quickly agents reduce contacts when symptomatic</li>
698         * <li>Affects the speed of organic transmission reduction</li>
699         * </ul>
700         *
701         * @return Exponential decay rate (days^-1)
702         */
703        Double getOrganicRateOfMobilityChange();
704
705        /**
706         * Gets the basic reproduction number (R0) for the disease.
707         *
708         * This is used by the {@link io.github.ai4ci.abm.Calibration calibration} in
709         * conjunction with the {@link #getContactProbability() contact probability},
710         * the viral load profile from {@link #getViralLoadProfile()}, and the
711         * network structure to calibrate the baseline per contact
712         * {@link io.github.ai4ci.abm.OutbreakBaseline#getViralLoadTransmissibilityParameter()
713         * transmission parameter}. This is in turn used to produce per contact
714         * transmission probability based on the in host viral load of the infected
715         * individual and the contact probabilities of the infected and susceptible
716         * individual.
717         *
718         * @return Average number of secondary cases from one infected individual
719         * @see #getContactProbability()
720         */
721        Double getR0();
722
723        /**
724         * Gets the kernel function for contact based risk assessment in the
725         * {@link RiskModel}. This kernel defines how the presence and timing of
726         * contacts with people who are themselves at risk of being infectious
727         * contribute to an individual's perceived risk of being infectious. This can
728         * be expressed as a {@link GaussianKernel}, {@link EmpiricalKernel} or
729         * {@link DiscreteFunction} depending on the desired shape of the risk
730         * contribution over time.
731         *
732         * @return KernelFunction defining the temporal risk contribution of contacts
733         *         in the RiskModel.
734         */
735        KernelFunction getRiskModelContactsKernel();
736
737        /**
738         * Gets the kernel function for symptom-based risk assessment in the
739         * {@link RiskModel}. This kernel defines how the presence and timing of
740         * symptoms contribute to an individual's perceived risk of being infectious
741         * given symptoms. This can be expressed as a {@link GaussianKernel},
742         * {@link EmpiricalKernel} or {@link DiscreteFunction} depending on the
743         * desired shape of the risk contribution over time.
744         *
745         * @return KernelFunction defining the temporal risk contribution of symptoms
746         *         in the RiskModel.
747         */
748        KernelFunction getRiskModelSymptomKernel();
749
750        /**
751         * Gets the kernel function for test results based risk assessment in the
752         * {@link RiskModel}. This kernel defines how the presence and timing of test
753         * results contribute to an individual's perceived risk of being infectious
754         * given a positive test result. This can be expressed as a
755         * {@link GaussianKernel}, {@link EmpiricalKernel} or
756         * {@link DiscreteFunction} depending on the desired shape of the risk
757         * contribution over time.
758         *
759         * @return KernelFunction defining the temporal risk contribution of test
760         *         results in the RiskModel.
761         */
762        KernelFunction getRiskModelTestKernel();
763        // Does this supercede the presumed incubation / infectious period
764        // parameters?
765
766        /**
767         * Generates severity profiles for disease progression from an average set of
768         * participants. The profiles are generated from the in-host model defined in
769         * the configuration and are used by the
770         * {@link io.github.ai4ci.abm.Calibration calibration} to calibrate the
771         * severity thresholds for asymptomatic, hospitalised, and fatal cases based
772         * on the desired case hospitalisation and fatality rates.
773         *
774         * @return DelayDistribution of symptom severity patterns
775         * @see InHostConfiguration#getSeverityProfile(ExecutionConfiguration, int,
776         *      int)
777         */
778        @JsonIgnore @Value.Lazy
779        default DelayDistribution getSeverityProfile() {
780                return InHostConfiguration.getSeverityProfile(this, 100, 100);
781        }
782
783        /**
784         * The local risk profile (assessed through tests, symptoms, contacts etc)
785         * which is sufficient to trigger a request for testing and reactive self
786         * isolation. This is used directly by the behaviour models to determine when
787         * an individual is deemed to be at high risk and should be advised to get
788         * tested and self isolate.
789         *
790         * @return Probability threshold for triggering testing and isolation based
791         *         on risk assessment (e.g., 0.05)
792         * @see io.github.ai4ci.abm.behaviour.SmartAgentTesting#REACTIVE_PCR
793         * @see io.github.ai4ci.abm.behaviour.SmartAgentLFTTesting#REACTIVE_LFT
794         */
795        Double getSmartAppRiskTrigger();
796
797        /**
798         * Gets the sensitivity of symptom-based detection. This parameter defines
799         * the probability at a population level that infected individuals will
800         * experience symptoms when they have disease
801         * {@link io.github.ai4ci.abm.PersonBaseline#getSymptomSensitivity()}. This
802         * is sampled for each individual to determine their baseline personal
803         * symptom sensitivity, which in turn affects the likelihood of symptom
804         * onset.
805         * <p>
806         * Individual-level impact (PersonBaseline):
807         * <ul>
808         * <li>Determines the likelihood of symptom onset in infected agents</li>
809         * <li>Affects the effectiveness of symptom-based interventions (e.g.,
810         * self-isolation, testing)</li>
811         * </ul>
812         *
813         * @return A probability distribution representing the population-level
814         *         symptom sensitivity (e.g., unimodal beta distribution)
815         */
816        Distribution getSymptomSensitivity();
817
818        /**
819         * Gets the specificity of symptom-based detection. The complement of this
820         * parameter defines the probability at a population level that uninfected
821         * individuals will experience symptoms that are mistaken for disease
822         * {@link io.github.ai4ci.abm.PersonBaseline#getSymptomSpecificity()}. This
823         * is sampled for each individual to determine their baseline personal
824         * symptom specificity, which in turn affects the baseline likelihood of
825         * false symptom onset.
826         * <p>
827         * Individual-level impact (PersonBaseline):
828         * <ul>
829         * <li>Determines the likelihood of false symptom onset in uninfected agents
830         * </li>
831         * <li>Affects the rate of false positives in symptom-based
832         * interventions</li>
833         * </ul>
834         *
835         * @return A probability distribution representing the population-level
836         *         symptom specificity (e.g., unimodal beta distribution)
837         */
838        Distribution getSymptomSpecificity();
839
840        /**
841         * For a configuration gets a set of viral load profiles from an average set
842         * of participants. The profiles are generated from the in-host model defined
843         * in the configuration and are used by the
844         * {@link io.github.ai4ci.abm.Calibration calibration} to calibrate the
845         * transmission parameter to achieve the desired R0.
846         *
847         * <p>
848         * Each profile is a time series of viral load values that represent the
849         * infectiousness of an individual over time after infection. The profiles
850         * are typically generated for a fixed number of time steps (e.g., 100) and
851         * can be used to determine the temporal dynamics of transmission in the
852         * model.
853         *
854         * <p>
855         * Because they undergo further transformation during calibration to produce
856         * the final transmission profile, they cannot be averaged at this stage
857         * (unlike {@link #getSeverityProfile()}) but they are generated from the
858         * same in-host model and parameters defined in the configuration to ensure
859         * consistency with the disease progression assumptions.
860         *
861         *
862         * @return 2D array of viral load profiles (time steps x number of profiles)
863         */
864        @JsonIgnore @Value.Lazy
865        default double[][] getViralLoadProfile() {
866                return InHostConfiguration.getViralLoadProfile(this, 100, 100);
867        }
868
869        /**
870         * Default implementation of withName that returns the same instance. This
871         * allows for immutability while still providing a fluent interface for
872         * setting the name property.
873         *
874         * @param name the name to set for this configuration
875         * @return the same instance of ExecutionConfiguration with the name set
876         *         (default implementation returns the same instance)
877         */
878        default ExecutionConfiguration withName(String name) {
879                return this;
880        }
881
882        /**
883         * Default implementations of withReplicate and withName that return the same
884         * instance. This allows for immutability while still providing a fluent
885         * interface for setting these properties.
886         *
887         * @param i the replicate number to set for this configuration
888         * @return the same instance of ExecutionConfiguration with the replicate
889         *         number set (default implementation returns the same instance)
890         */
891        default ExecutionConfiguration withReplicate(Integer i) {
892                return this;
893        }
894
895}
